channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Petition Seeks Closure of Extrajudicial Detention Centers
item.description: A letter signed by 109 lawyers, scholars and activists calling on the state to abolish the “custody and education” system, an extralegal punishment operated by the police, was delivered to the National People’s Congress on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Trial of Oscar Pistorius Resumes in South Africa
item.description: The athlete’s defense is expected to try to buttress its case that he acted in self-defense and shot his girlfriend by accident.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: 11 Missing After Cargo Ships Collide Near Hong Kong
item.description: One person was rescued after a Chinese cargo ship carrying 12 people sank after colliding with a container ship, local news reports said.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: After Failed Peace Talks, Pushing to Label Israel as Occupier of Palestine
item.description: Palestinian leaders have plans to join the International Criminal Court in The Hague, which experts say could prosecute Israel for settlement building in territories that Palestinians claim.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: May 5
item.description: A roundup of the local election-related news for Monday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Supporters waving at a helicopter carrying Akhilesh Yadav, chief minister of the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh, at a rally on the outskirts of Allahabad on Wednesday.

item.title: Officials Plan Next Phase of Search for Missing Plane
item.description: New equipment will be deployed with help from outside groups and companies as the search continues for debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Sentences Accused Spy to 10-Year Prison Term
item.description: The accused spy was contacted through an online messaging service and asked to pass along military journals available only to domestic Chinese subscribers, according to a state-run newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Incumbent’s Party Loses Presidency in Panama
item.description: Vice President Juan Carlos Varela, who broke with the governing party in a rancorous falling-out, was declared the president-elect, capturing 39 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Voters lined up at a polling station outside Panama City for the presidential election on Sunday. The election commission declared Juan Carlos Varela, an opposition candidate, the winner.

item.title: Kiev’s Reins Weaken as Chaos Spreads
item.description: Russian-speaking regions spun further out of the central government’s control as a mob stormed a police station in Odessa, Ukraine, and freed from detention 67 pro-Russian militants.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man who was one of 67 pro-Russian militants who were released from a police station on Sunday after the building was stormed in Odessa, Ukraine.

item.title: Kiev Struggles to Break Russia’s Grip on Gas Flow
item.description: A plan to reverse-flow natural gas into Ukraine from the European Union has been hindered by neighboring Slovakia’s reticence, seemingly due to pressure from Russia’s state-owned energy behemoth.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.media:description: A natural gas worker in Chaslovtsy, the largest transit point in Ukraine for Gazprom exports to the European Union.

item.title: South Africa President Appeals for Ex-Backers to Return to Fold
item.description: Days before the general election, President Jacob Zuma extended a conciliatory hand to former colleagues, allies and backers who had become bitter rivals and critics.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: An African National Congress election campaign mural in Johannesburg, South Africa. The A.N.C. is expected to win the general election on Wednesday, but with reduced margins.

item.title: Libya Leader Finally Picked but Is Quickly Challenged
item.description: Confusion surrounded the election of Ahmed Maitiq as prime minister, dealing another blow to a transitional government that has struggled to find coherence.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: More Dead in Colombia Mine Collapse
item.description: The death toll in a collapse at an illegal gold mine in western Colombia rose to at least 12 as searchers continued to dig for bodies on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Fresh Doubts Raised About Papyrus Scrap Known as ‘Gospel of Jesus’ Wife’
item.description: A relic has provoked fascination and fury since it was unveiled nearly two years ago by an eminent historian of early Christianity at Harvard Divinity School.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Left, a scrap of papyrus known as the “Gospel of Jesus’s Wife” compared with a strikingly similar fragment, “Gospel of John.” Both seem to be written by the same hand.

item.title: Bombs Explode on Two Buses Packed With Kenya Commuters
item.description: Three people were killed and at least 60 wounded, a day after a grenade attack at a bus stop in the coastal city of Mombasa killed four people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Tokyo Is Shaken by Strong Quake
item.description: The strongest quake felt in the Japanese capital since the aftershocks of a magnitude-9 earthquake and tsunami in March 2011 off the northeastern coast.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: London Journal: From Riots and Rebels to Juice Bars and Tapas, a New Brixton Emerges
item.description: The London neighborhood of Brixton, long one of the capital’s most downtrodden areas, has recently seen a quickening in its decades-long gentrification.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stalls in Brixton Village, where fancy French fare is now available in a market that the police once called a “24-hour drug supermarket.”

item.title: Survivors’ Hopes Fade in Aftermath of Afghan Landslide
item.description: In one of the biggest natural disasters visited on Afghanistan in more than a decade, hundreds have lost wives, children, mothers and fathers.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A displaced villager from Abi Barak shielded himself and his child in a makeshift shelter on Sunday. A massive landslide on Friday buried more than 2,000 people in Badakhshan Province in Afghanistan.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Manzur's Lonely End
item.description: My uncle died sadly isolated – an increasingly common predicament in Bangladesh’s aging society.
item.dc:creator: By TAHMIMA ANAM

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Uighur Father’s Brave Fight
item.description: My father, Ilham Tohti, an outspoken critic of China's policies on our people, has been jailed. I must tell his story.
item.dc:creator: By JEWHER ILHAM

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Muzzling Pakistan's Media
item.description: Attempts to silence the press will fail. The army's latest intimidation campaign is a sign of weakness, not strength.
item.dc:creator: By HASAN ZAIDI

item.title: South Sudan Captures Stronghold of Rebels
item.description: Government troops retook two important northern towns just days after South Sudan’s president told the United States that he would hold talks with his rebel opponent, Riek Machar, the country’s former vice president.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government soldiers marched Sunday toward Bentiu, the capital of Unity State.

item.title: Buoyed by Exports, Portugal Chooses Clean Exit From Bailout
item.description: With promising signs of growth and falling unemployment, Portugal’s prime minister, Pedro Passos Coelho, announced an end to his country’s three-year, $108 billion bailout.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lisbon will not ask lenders for a precautionary credit line, which could be tapped if the country’s finances deteriorate and it needs more European rescue funding.

item.title: ScienceTake: A Desert Spider With Astonishing Moves
item.description: The Moroccan spider, newly discovered, is called the flic-flac for its leap, which resembles a gymnast’s handspring.
item.dc:creator: By SINDYA N. BHANOO
item.media:description: Cebrennus rechenbergi in the midst of its "flic-flac" maneuver.

item.title: Train Derails in India, Killing at Least 18
item.description: More than 125 others were injured when the train’s engine and four of its 20 cars derailed after they emerged from a tunnel in the Raigad district.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
